Variation Example: On their way Christ & St. Peter meet a lazy man lying in the grass. When they ask him for the way, he points out the direction with his foot. Later they meet a hard-working girl who leads them briskly on their way. When St. Peter asks how the girl should be re-warded, Christ answers that the two people should marry, for then they would complement one another.

A supernatural being (devil) lends money to a poor man on the condition that he will claim the man’s soul if the man does not repay the debt within one year. When the poor man comes to pay his debt, the supernatural being is no longer there (is dead, is killed by lightning or has been disappeared secretly). In some variants the farmer avoids having to repay his debt to the devil by giving excuses, or he exempts himself from the obligation to pay by solving the devil’s riddles, by destroy ing the written agreement, or by giving the devil a brooding hen instead of his mother or his “pungent smell” instead of his soul.

Classifications: A Mother Dies of Fright When She Learns that she was about to commit Incest with her son
Variation Example: A mother (of Solomon) has a rendezvous with a young man. Her son (Solomon) disguises himself & goes to the meeting place instead of the young man in order to test her chastity. (The mother caresses him & he denounces her. She curses him: the tree should swallow him. Solomon carves a violin while sitting inside the tree.)

Classifications: The Devil Lets the Man see his Wife's Unfaithfulness
Variation Example: He transforms the husband into a goat which he brings to see his wife & her lover. In some variants the devil (wood spirit) shows a man how false his wife is by bringing her a sack of gold. In order to keep the money, she agrees to cut off the head of her sleeping husband. The man awakes in time & punishes his wife.

This misc. type comprises various anecdotes dealing with the devil in Noah’s ark. The motifs mentioned do not all occur in any single variant. God commands Noah to build the ark in secret to escape the deluge. In order to keep the work secret, the hammer is silent or the axe never gets dull on the stone chopping block. The devil finds out the secret of the construction of the ark from Noah’s wife. He persuades her to give Noah an intoxicating drink, so Noah tells his secret & the devil destroys the ark. Noah weeps & an angel instructs him how to rebuild it. By performing a washing ritual (water circle) Noah is able to keep the devil away from the ark. A gong calls the animals to board the ark. Some creatures are barred but finally they all enter: the serpent, the insects, the fly, fabulous creatures like the unicorn, the phoenix & the giant. By a ruse the devil manages to enter the ark: he hides near Noah’s wife (at her breast, in her work-basket, in her shadow). She does not enter the ark until Noah calls her with a curse addressed to the devil. On board, the devil, in the form of a mouse, gnaws a hole in the ark & tries to sink it, but a cat swallows the mouse. Helpful animals (serpent, hare, fish, dog) offer to close the hole with part of their body (tail, nose); smaller animals (tortoise, salamander, rabbit) are used as a plug. The serpent demands fresh (human) blood every day for its help. After the deluge, Noah throws the serpent into a holy fire. Its ashes spread with the wind & turn into bloodsucking fleas (lice, mosquitos) .

A pious clergyman has a vision in church: he sees the devil at the altar writing down all the sins of the participants of the mass. In the name of God he takes the list, reads it to the community, & everyone repents. The devil leaves the church.

Classifications: A Pious Innocent Man Knows Nothing of God
Variation Example: A pious man (farmer) worships God in his own way & never goes to church. A traveling preacher teaches him how to pray properly & continues on his way. When the pious man forgets the prayer he follows the preacher’s ship by walking on the water. By this miracle the preacher recognizes the man’s holiness & understands that pious innocence is pleasing to God.

A lazy man grumbles against God because he feels neglected. An old man advises him to set a trap, & God will certainly help him. The lazy man follows his advice & catches a deer. While he is skinning the animal the old man reappears & points out that God had helped him. But the lazy man emphasizes his own ability. The old man revives the deer & it runs away The lazy man understands too late that God helped him to catch the deer. In some variants the white spots on the deer’s belly (the bones on the leg resembling a knife, the grey hair on the leg) are explained as a result of the skinning process.

Classifications: My Crops will Thrive Here Without God's Blessing
Variation Example: This tale exists chiefly in four different forms: (1) A farmer sows crops. Unrecognized saints (God) wish him God’s blessing & a good harvest, but the farmer replies his crops will thrive without God’s blessing. When weeds grow in his field, the farmer is converted. (2) A poor & a rich man (farmer, sower, two brothers) sow crops. Saints (passersby) greet the poor farmer, “May God help you!” The farmer thanks them for the greetings & is rewarded with a good harvest. The saints greet the rich in the same way, but he rejects their greetings by saying that his crops will also grow without God’s blessing. His harvest is very poor & he repents his behavior too late. (3) The discourteous sower. A passerby (God) asks a farmer what he is sowing. Rudely he answers that he is sowing stones. The passerby wishes him a good harvest, which turns out to be stone plants. (A farmer tells Christ that he is sowing pumpkins [turnips], though his seed is maize. Thereupon he harvests only pumpkins.) (4) Weather forecast. Christ asks farmers if there will be rain. Two answer that frogs (foxes, other animals) predict rain. The third farmer says that he prays to God for rain. Only the last is blessed with rain.

This misc. type comprises various tales, all of which connect the phrase “If God wills” with an event in an instructive or funny way. In most variants a person’s efforts meet with successive misfortunes because he forgets to say, “If God wills”.

Classifications: The Clergyman in Disguise as the Devil
Variation Example: This tale exists chiefly in two different forms: (1) A poor, miserable man finds (advised in a dream, through an angel) a treasure (receives money from God), & tells a clergyman (priest, landlord, rich neighbor) about it. The clergyman disguises himself in an animal skin & pretends to be the devil. He frightens the poor man & takes the treasure. But at home he cannot take the skin off (until the stolen treasure has been returned). (2) The rich man (miller, butcher, baker) fails to take the treasure because the devil himself in disguise as a traveler (black horseman, soldier, hunter) stays at the poor man’s house as an overnight guest (meets him on his way) & kills (abducts) the rich man.

A fisherman always catches three fishes (bread) for himself (his wife, & his child [children]). The greedy parents kill the child (expose the children) in order to have more fish (bread) for themselves. But from then on the man catches only two fish (the fish disappear completely, they do not have any more bread).

This misc. type comprises various tales all featuring the phrase “God determines” or “God will care for all”. A person (spouse, brother, sister, girl, man, relative, a rich, a lazy man, neighbor, friend, servant) tells his dream to another person (spouse, brother, sister, relative, a poor, neighbor, friend, servant) saying that in a certain place a treasure is buried (finds a treasure). The second person tries to dig up the treasure at the indicated spot (tries to dig up a treasure at the same spot), or a third person (thieves, neighbor) overhears the conversation & digs there. But instead of the treasure the person unearths only a dead dog (dead cat, some toads, beetles, pot of ants, pot of serpents, pot of glowing embers, pot of dung, skeleton). Angered by this deception he/she throws the animal (pot) into the house (bed, through the window, through the roof) of the dreamer, & everything is transformed into gold (silver, money).

A rich man (woman) boasts (often during mass) in his thoughts (in a conversation) that his wealth is so immense that even God could never take it away. When he returns home his property is completely destroyed (house has burned down) & he stays poor for the rest of his life.

A man rubs ointment on his left eye & tells a miser that he can see the treasures of the world. The miser copies him & sees mountains of gold. When he wants to rub oint ment on the right eye as well the man advises him not to do so for he will become blind. The miser does not listen & rubs it on his right eye. He is immediately blinded & becomes a beggar.

A beggar (female beggar) periodically receives a loaf from a rich man (his wife). (A rich miser refuses to give food to a beggar.) When ever the beggar receives the bread he states, “Everything you do, you do it to yourself!” The rich man becomes tired of this (angry about the beggar’s words, wants to get rid of the beggar) so he (and his wife) puts poison into the beggar’s bread. Further on his way the beggar meets a hungry young man (traveler) to whom he gives his bread. The young man dies & it turns out that he is the son of the rich man. So the beggar’s state ment was true.

From his childhood a mother (in older variants: father) teaches her son to steal (she does not prevent him from stealing). He is caught & condemned to death. On the gallows he asks for permission to kiss his mother for the last time & bites off her nose (tongue, ear). He explains that she taught him to steal (that she spoiled him as a child, that this is her punishment for her neglect).

Classifications: One Vice Carries Other With It
Variation Example: (The Three Sins of the Hermit.) A man (hermit, monk) has to choose one of the following vices: theft (murder), lust, drinking. He chooses the last, which seems him to be the least harmful. But when he is drunk, all the other vices follow in its wake.

In order to tempt a hermit (bishop, monks), the devil (devils) disguised as a clergyman tries to rejuvenate him or to get him married. Or, a man (pupil of the bishop) is suspected of being a devil because he does not cross himself & leaves the church when in cense is burned & benedictions are said. The brother of the hermit (old man, poor man, monks) overhears the devils discuss their plan sitting under a tree (near a well, at a rock), & warns the hermit. The hermit orders all doors, windows, holes, etc. of the church to be closed. When he burns incense & asks for heaven’s blessings, the devil bursts & mice (spiders) jump out of his mouth. The bishop throws his gloves, which turn into cats & catch the mice. Or the hermit crosses himself & in place of the church (forge), only a stake remains.

When a father & his son (travelers) pass the night in a certain house, the son is unable to sleep. He sees wonder ful things happening: a snake creeps from a sleeping man’s mouth into his wife’s mouth; a man’s head is split by an axe, etc. In the morning the master of the house explains that these are punishments of mankind (he explains that the visions were caused by family disharmony & quarrels).

A virtuous man, a robber, & a thief (clergyman, farmer & host [teacher]) ask a hermit (old man, God) about their fate (which of them is most certain to go to heaven). He tells them to take three different roads, where they spend the night in various situations. When they come back & tell about their experiences (the first sleeps in a fine house, the second in a forest during a storm & the third in water), the hermit explains that the experiences they had foretell their conditions of life in future.

Classifications: One Beggar Trusts God, the Other the King
Variation Example: Two beggars (blind men, shoemakers, craftsmen), one of whom asks God for help the other of whom asks the king (emperor, sultan, mas-ter), receive two loaves (flat cake, cakes, roasted chicken) from the king. In one of the loaves nothing (bones) is hidden, the other one is filled with (pieces of) gold. By this gift the king intended to reward the beggar who had asked for his help, & to demonstrate his secular power. But the beggars exchange their loaves, because the one who trusted in secular power thought that his loaf was not well baked because it was so heavy. When the king learns about the exchange he agrees that God’s power is stronger than his own.

Classifications: The Beggar Dies in Night Lodgings
Variation Example: A large sum of money is found in a dead beggar’s clothes (sewn up in his coat). On a clergyman’s advice, the money is used to buy pigs & fatten them. All the pigs are slaughtered except one, which leads the clergyman to the graveyard, where it sinks into the dead beggar’s grave (the beggar is seen riding in flames on one of the pigs to hell). It shows that the money was acquired in a dishonest way.
Coins earned by hard work float on water & bring happiness.
When she sees how a persistent little bird pecks a hole in a stone, she resumes her work diligently.

A ruler (king, mayor, sovereign couple) is sick (unhappy). A doctor (wise man, hermit) advises him to wear (to look for) the shirt of a lucky man. Servants are sent out to look (the ruler himself looks) for such a man, but a lucky man cannot be found. Finally they meet a poor man (shepherd, boy) who seems to fit the requirement. But it turns out that the man has no shirt. The king dies (realizes that luck cannot be bought).

Classifications: The Revenge of the Castrated Man
Variation Example: A male slave (servant, farmhand) who had been punished for a serious crime (adultery) by castration (blinding) blackmails his master to be mutilated (to mutilate himself) by threatening to kill his children (sons, wife). When the man has obeyed, the slave kills the children anyway.
A man (poor people) who is unhappy with his situation has the opportunity to trade (in a shop) his cross (bag of sorrows) with another one. He discovers that his own fate fits him better.

An old man has to carry a heavy load of wood a long way. Tired & exhausted, he puts it down & wishes for death. When death appears & asks why he had been called, the old man explains, “I want you to help me with the load!”

God & the devil go for a walk on earth . The devil complains about men’s injustice (after being criticized by God for his impoliteness: he did not answer the people’s greetings & showed them his tongue). He is always blamed for God’s mistakes, but whenever he does something well, God receives the thanks. The devil proves it by pushing a cow (horse, ox) into a ditch. The farmer blames him by asking which damned devil had done that. While the farmer fetches help in the village the devil pulls the animal out of the ditch. When the farmer comes back & sees that his cow has been saved, he exclaims, “Thank God!”

A man (farmer, shepherd) praises only one of the saints (on his nameday) & disparages the others. The neglected saint takes revenge by sending hail & a bad harvest. But the praised one helps the man & informs him about the other saint’s plans. In another variant the saints dispute as to which of them the man addressed his words, “Good day”.

A merchant borrows money, leaving a cross (icon) as security. During a storm, fearing a shipwreck, he throws a barrel with the money into the water. The barrel floats back to the creditor. In another version a poor man borrows flour from a rich man, leaving an icon of St. Nicholas as security. The rich man threatens to destroy the icon if it is not redeemed in time. A young man over-hears the deal, procures money, redeems the icon, & places it in his mother’s house. In order to earn money he decides to sell goods at a fair. On his way he gives a lift to an old man who later helps him to endure dangers during a wake. Finally the old man revives the dead daughter of the czar & the young man marries her. The old man makes the young wife into a happy, healthy person before he leaves. The young couple returns to the boy’s mother where they learn that the icon is back in its usual place, but that it had disappeared for a while.

A princess is promised in marriage to whoever is able to describe her birthmarks. A young swineherd (shepherd, tailor) has hogs (geese) that dance to his magic flute. In return for his dancing hogs the princess lets the shepherd boy see her naked & thus he comes to know her secret birthmarks. Or a fisherman offers the princess colorful fishes. In return she undresses herself three times, so that finally he knows the answer. Another suitor (rich man) guesses the answer. As both rivals have solved the riddle, the king then gives a further test: the princess is to marry the suitor to whom she turns in the night. The rivals sleep with her & she turns to the shepherd (because his rival has eaten bad-smelling food or has soiled the bed).

Classifications: The Princess Who Cannot Solve the Riddle
Variation Example: A princess is offered in marriage to whoever can pose a riddle that she cannot solve. A man (prince, stupid boy, shepherd) makes a riddle based on unusual circum-stances which he has witnessed (experienced). (She marries him at this point & the tale ends here.) She sends her maidservants & then goes herself to him at night to learn the answer. He keeps her nightdress (braid) as proof. In court, she answers his riddle but permits him to ask an-other. It refers to her night visit, & rather than answer it, she agrees to marry him. Different riddles are used, for example: (1) I ride on my father & wear (carry) my mother – he has sold his parents & bought a horse & clothes (gun). (2) I ate (am) the unborn – a fetal animal (he was cut from his mother’s womb). (3) I drank water from neither heaven nor earth – horse’s sweat (conden sation from a lamp). (4) One killed three & three killed twelve – his horse was poisoned, birds ate it, thieves ate the birds, & all died. In Turandot the princess herself is the one to set riddles for her suitors to answer: riddle of the sun, of the ocean of the year. If they are not able to find the solution they will be punished by death.

A princess is offered in marriage to the man who can tell so big a lie that she (her father) will exclaim, “That is a lie”. A suitor tells impossible tales of his extraordinary great ox, of a tree that grows to the sky overnight, of a river of honey, of his ascent & descent on a rope of chaff from the sky, of a great cabbage, stable, animals, mushroom, large man, a man who cuts off his head & replaces it, a man who cuts ice with his own hands or of a man who drinks water from his skull. When finally the suitor states that her father served his father as swineherd (when he threatens to report [falsely] her amorous conduct), the princess (king) is brought to say the required words & she has to marry the suitor.

Classifications: Hero Catches Princess with Her Own Words
Variation Example: A princess is offered in marriage to any man who outwits her in repartee. On the way to the contest the young est of three brothers (stupid boy, suitor) picks up rubbish: a dead crow, an egg, & other objects. The (two) elder brothers fail in talking to the princess. The youngest brother, by producing these objects at the proper time, is able to give an eloquent (often obscene) answer to each of the princess’ questions. He wins her as his bride. In some variants he is imprisoned & escapes by means of his magic tablecloth, magic purse & magic fiddle. He uses his magic fiddle to capture the princess & will release her only if she says, “No” to all his questions. By this means he wins her to his desires & marries her

A king with a daughter of a marriageable age is told about the conversation of three of his officers (suitors, young men, soldiers). One says that he intends to love the queen, another wants to sleep with the princess, the third wants gold. The first gets nothing, the third receives the gold. Then the king advises his daughter that she must answer all the questions of the second suitor (suitors who wanted to sleep with the princess) with “No”. By a clever framing of his questions the suitor overcomes her resistance & marries her (the princess agrees to the suitor’s question by saying “No”).

A young man (soldier) writes on a wall (states), “Money is all powerful” (“With money one can even win the princess”). The king is provoked & sets what he believes to be an impossible task. The young man receives as much money as he wants, but within a certain time he has to seduce (find) the princess. If he fails he will be condemned to death. The princess is hidden in a secret place (tower, room under earth, island, secret room, iron palace at the bottom of the sea) & guarded. The young man demands a hollow golden (silver, copper) animal statue (ram, goat, lion, deer, elephant, ox, horse, dancing bear, bird, eagle) & hides inside it. The king buys the statue (which can play music) & installs it in his daughter’s room as en-ter tainmen At night the youth steals out of the statue & amuses himself with the princess. When the statue is damaged it has to be sent for repair, & the youth comes out. Having won the contest the youth may now marry the princess (after she has become pregnant or has given birth to his child). In some variants a king offers his daughter to whoever is able to find her. Three sons of a merchant travel & reach the town where the contest is held. Two of them fail to find the princess & are killed. The third, on the advice of an old woman, orders a hollow golden animal, inside of which he is carried into the secret hiding place of the princess. When the statue is damaged it is taken back. In this way the suitor comes out again & is able to describe the way to the princess’s hiding place (to show a token) to the king. Or, the suitor has to recognize the princess among several similar looking girls or animals; the princess helps him by giving a sign.

A handsome youth is hired to take the place of a one-eyed (crippled) prince (merchant’s son) at the latter’s wedding. The bride falls in love with the youth & refuses the one-eyed prince. In some variants the young man escapes with the bride. Or, the one-eyed prince is tested. He cannot remember the conversation between the bride & the youth on the preceding night Sometimes the bride searches for the young man & eventually finds him. She gives alms to all passersby, until eventually she recognizes her husband. In other variants the bride offers a reward to all those who tell her a story. The young man appears & tells his story. Or, the youth has left his name (a verse) with the bride. In numerous variants it is predicted that the young man will die at the age of twelve (sixteen) but he outwits this fate.

A youth is driven away by his father when he states that he will marry four wives. While acting as a servant, the youth pretends to be unable to read. He is given a message & learns that the princess intends to elope with the son of a court official. He informs the court official who locks up his son. The youth takes his place & elopes with the princess. At daybreak the princess realizes she cannot return to her par-ents. The young man is bitten by a snake & restored to life by a girl whom he marries. In the form of a parrot he is bought by another princess, whom he marries as well. Forced to flee, he hides in the house of a rich merchant & marries his daughter. Finally he returns to his father with his four wives.
